child.pub-comments: "As I am uncertain of the phonological history of the Gelao languages, they are omitted from this [lexicostatistical] classification" (Peiros 1998:14).

child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
child.pub-comments: "There is no commonly accepted name for the language family which includes languages related to Siamese or Thai. Shafer (1974) used the term 'Daic' for this family, but I prefer to call it 'Kadai', following the suggestion by Haudricourt (1967) accepted by Benedict (1975, 1990)" (Peiros 1998:11).

child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
child.pub-comments: "Thus, my conclusion is that the comparisons do suggest that Kadai languages are related to the Austronesian family, but that we need much more data before this suggestion is proved" (Peiros 1998:103).

child.pub-comments: This subgroup is not included in the author's lexicostatistical analysis. "The Pearic group (Pear, Samre, Angrak, etc.) is only superficially known. Just one vocabulary is in print (Headley 1978) and there is no sufficient data for the internal analysis of the group (cf. however Headley 1985)" (Peiros 1998:105).

child.pub-comments: "It is highly possible that Thin, Mlabri (Rischel 1995), and some other poorly known languages should be grouped together with Khmuic (Diffloth 1985)" (Peiros 1998:106).

child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
child.pub-comments: "This tentative [lexicostatistical] classification reveals several important features. It lacks any clear distinction between Mundari of the Munda branch and the rest of the languages traditionally included in the Mon-Khmer family. Instead six equal groups have been identified: [Central, Vietic, Northern, Khmer, Khasi, Munda]" (Peiros 1998:113).

child.pub-comments: "It is unclear whether one can identify Taipan with the Biaomon dialect of the Chinese classification" (Peiros 1998:123).

child.geography: These languages mainly occur in a spread across Southern China and neighbouring areas of Vietnam, Laos, and Thailand
child.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
child.pub-comments: "I believe that the list supports (although it does not prove) the existence of a genetic relationship between Miao-Yao and the Mon-Khmer (and thus Austroasiatic) family, as Haudricourt and Jakhontov proposed. […] The Miao-Yao family, it seems, is not a branch of Austroasiatic, but forms with it a genetic unit which could be called the 'Miao-Austroasiatic' (macro)family" (Peiros 1998: 160).

root.publications: Peiros, Ilia. 1998. Comparative Linguistics in Southeast Asia, vol. 142. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics, Series C.
root.pub-comments: "Unfortunately, at present I cannot add more detail to this suggestion about the genetic affiliations of the four language families of Southeast Asia. Much time-consuming work is necessary before the existence of the Austric macrofamily can be proved according to the formal procedures of historical linguistics" (Peiros 1998:168).
